words.definition: A reusable, self-contained building block for UIs in React and Next.js.
words.example: Each button is a separate component.
examples: Components can be nested and composed.

words.definition: Inputs passed to a component to customize its behavior or appearance.
words.example: Props pass data from parent to child components.
examples: Use props to configure a button's label.

words.definition: Internal data managed by a component that determines its dynamic behavior.
words.example: State tracks user input in a form.
examples: State updates cause components to re-render.

words.definition: A special function in React for managing state, lifecycle, or side effects in functional components.
words.example: The useEffect hook runs code after rendering.
examples: Custom hooks encapsulate reusable logic.

words.definition: A React hook for adding state to functional components.
words.example: useState manages the count value.
examples: const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

words.definition: A React hook for handling side effects such as data fetching or subscriptions.
words.example: useEffect runs after every render by default.
examples: useEffect(() => { fetchData(); }, []);

words.definition: A way to share data globally across the component tree without passing props manually at every level.
words.example: Theme context provides color settings to all components.
examples: Context is useful for authentication state.

words.definition: A component that supplies context data to its descendants.
words.example: Wrap your app in a ThemeProvider.
examples: Providers are used with React context.

words.definition: A component or function that reads data from a React context.
words.example: Consumers access values from the nearest provider.
examples: useContext is a consumer hook.

words.definition: A syntax extension for JavaScript that allows writing HTML-like code in React components.
words.example: JSX makes UI code more readable.
examples: JSX is compiled to JavaScript.

words.definition: A TypeScript extension for JSX, used in React components with TypeScript.
words.example: TSX files combine TypeScript and JSX syntax.
examples: Use .tsx for typed React components.

words.definition: To generate and display UI elements based on code and data.
words.example: React components render UI from props and state.
examples: The render function returns JSX.

words.definition: A lightweight copy of the real DOM used by React to optimize UI updates.
words.example: The virtual DOM improves rendering speed.
examples: React computes changes in the virtual DOM before updating the real DOM.

words.definition: The process by which React updates the DOM by comparing the new virtual DOM with the previous one and applying minimal changes.
words.example: Reconciliation ensures efficient UI updates.
examples: React's diffing algorithm handles reconciliation.

words.definition: A React feature that allows grouping multiple elements without adding extra nodes to the DOM.
words.example: Use fragments to return multiple elements from a component.
examples: <>...</> is a shorthand for React.Fragment.

words.definition: A React feature for rendering children into a DOM node outside the parent component hierarchy.
words.example: Portals are used for modals and tooltips.
examples: ReactDOM.createPortal renders elements elsewhere in the DOM.

words.definition: A React object that provides a way to access or interact with a DOM element or component instance.
words.example: Refs are used to focus input fields programmatically.
examples: useRef creates a ref object.

words.definition: A React hook for creating a mutable ref object that persists across renders.
words.example: useRef is used to store a reference to a DOM element.
examples: const inputRef = useRef(null);

words.definition: A React hook for accessing the current value of a context.
words.example: useContext retrieves authentication data from AuthContext.
examples: const theme = useContext(ThemeContext);

words.definition: A React hook that memoizes the result of a function to optimize performance.
words.example: useMemo caches expensive computations.
examples: const filtered = useMemo(() => items.filter(...), [items]);

words.definition: A React hook that memoizes a callback function to prevent unnecessary re-renders.
words.example: useCallback is used for event handlers.
examples: const handleClick = useCallback(() => {...}, []);

words.definition: A React hook for managing complex state logic using reducers.
words.example: useReducer is useful for state machines.
examples: const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, initialState);

words.definition: A reusable function that starts with 'use' and encapsulates React hook logic.
words.example: Create a custom hook for form validation.
examples: Custom hooks simplify code reuse.

words.definition: A function that takes a component and returns a new component with enhanced behavior.
words.example: withAuth is a higher-order component for authentication.
examples: HOCs are used for cross-cutting concerns.

words.definition: A technique for sharing code between components using a function prop that returns elements.
words.example: A render prop provides custom rendering logic.
examples: Use render props for flexible UIs.

words.definition: A React component that catches JavaScript errors in its child component tree and displays a fallback UI.
words.example: Wrap your app in an error boundary to handle crashes.
examples: Error boundaries prevent entire app crashes.

words.definition: A React feature for handling asynchronous loading of components with fallback UIs.
words.example: Use Suspense to show loading spinners.
examples: Suspense works with lazy-loaded components.

words.definition: A React function for code-splitting and loading components only when needed.
words.example: React.lazy enables on-demand loading.
examples: Combine lazy with Suspense for dynamic imports.

words.definition: A JavaScript feature for loading modules asynchronously, used in React for code-splitting.
words.example: Dynamic imports reduce initial bundle size.
examples: Next.js supports dynamic imports for components.

words.definition: A Next.js function for fetching data at request time for server-side rendering.
words.example: getServerSideProps runs on every page request.
examples: Use getServerSideProps for dynamic SSR pages.

words.definition: A Next.js function for fetching data at build time for static site generation.
words.example: getStaticProps pre-renders pages at build.
examples: Use getStaticProps for blog posts.

words.definition: A Next.js function for specifying dynamic routes to pre-render with getStaticProps.
words.example: getStaticPaths defines which blog pages to build.
examples: Use getStaticPaths for dynamic SSG routes.

words.definition: Incremental Static Regeneration, a Next.js feature that updates static pages after deployment without rebuilding the whole site.
words.example: ISR enables real-time content updates.
examples: ISR combines SSG speed with dynamic content.

words.definition: A Next.js folder for organizing application routes and layouts using the new app router.
words.example: The app directory replaces the pages directory in Next.js 13+.
examples: App directory enables advanced routing and layouts.

words.definition: Props passed to a Next.js page component, often from getServerSideProps or getStaticProps.
words.example: Page props contain data fetched for rendering.
examples: Access page props in your page component.

words.definition: A loading or placeholder UI shown while a dynamic or static page is being generated or loaded.
words.example: Show a fallback while data loads.
examples: Fallbacks improve user experience during loading.
